All methods provided by canEvent assume that they are mixed into an object -- this should be the object dispatching the events.

can-view-nodelist.name: can-view-nodelist
can-view-nodelist.description:
Adds nesting of text nodes can.view.nodeLists are used to make sure "directly nested" live-binding sections update content correctly. Consider the following template:
{{#if items.length}} Items: {{#items}} {{/items}} {{/if}}
The {{#if}} and {{#items}} seconds are "directly nested" because they share the same
parent element. If {{#items}} changes the DOM by adding more , {{#if}} needs to know about the to remove them if {{#if}} is re-rendered. {{#if}} would be re-rendered, for example, if all items were removed.

cloneNode.name: cloneNode

uses innerHTML instead, which has been shimmed.

canjs.name: canjs
canjs.title: CanJS
canjs.description:
CanJS is an evolving and improving set of client side JavaScript architectural libraries that balances innovation and stability. It targets experienced developers building complex applications with long futures ahead of them.


If you’re new to the project, the best place to start is the about page, where you’ll
find CanJS’s Mission and Technical Highlights. Then, go to the guides page to find
the Chat, TodoMVC, and ATM guides.

guides.name: guides
guides.title: Guides
guides.description: Welcome to CanJS! These guides are here to help you develop and improve your relationship with CanJS. After all, picking a JavaScript framework is a commitment.  We want CanJS to be the framework you marry.  This page helps you know how to advance through the different stages of this relationship:

can-component.prototype.ViewModel.name: can-component.prototype.ViewModel
can-component.prototype.ViewModel.title: ViewModel
can-component.prototype.ViewModel.description:
Provides or describes a constructor function that provides values and methods
to the component’s template. The constructor function
is initialized with values specified by the component element’s data bindings.

can-component/beforeremove.name: can-component/beforeremove
can-component/beforeremove.title: beforeremove
can-component/beforeremove.description:
An event called only on component’s elements before they are removed from the
document if live binding is performing the removal. It can be listened to
within a component’s can-component.prototype.events object or on a component
element with can-stache-bindings.event bindings.  This is an additional
special event only on component elements.  inserted
and removed events are available on all elements.

can-connect-signalr.init.description:
Establishes a connection to the SignalR hub, sets up proxy methods and RPC listeners.
The init method establishes a connection to the SignalR hub, and creates a hub proxy. For each CRUD method,
a corresponding RPC listener is registered on the proxy. For example, can-connect-signalr implements a createData
method. The listener corresponding to that method, by default called createdData, is registered on the proxy.
The init method is called automatically.

The can.Map plugin will works alongside can.Map.define to add validation to properties on a can.Map. Importing the plugin, validation library, and a shim will

can-validate-legacy.shims.description:

Creating a shim requires just three methods, isValid, once, and validate.
The shim should also import the validation library itself. The shim then registers

can-validate-legacy.name: can-validate-legacy

can-zone.ZoneSpec.name: can-zone.ZoneSpec
can-zone.ZoneSpec.title: ZoneSpec
can-zone.ZoneSpec.description:
A ZoneSpec is the way you tap into the lifecycle hooks of a Zone. The hooks are described below.
Using these hooks you can do things like create timers and override global variables that will change the shape of code that runs within the Zone.

can-zone.makeZoneSpec.name: can-zone.makeZoneSpec

can-zone/register.name: can-zone/register
can-zone/register.title: can-zone/register
can-zone/register.description:
In order to do it's magic, can-zone has to register handlers for all of the common JavaScript async operations. If you have code (or a dependency with this code) that does:
var st = setTimeout;

And this module loads before can-zone, any time st is used we won't be able to track that within the Zone.
To work around this, can-zone/register is used as a script that you run before any other modules.
In Node
require("can-zone/register");

At the top of your entry-point script.
In the Browser
You can either add a script tag above all others:
<script src="node_modules/can-zone/register.js"></script>

Or, if you're using a module loader / bundler, configure it so that can-zone/register is placed above all others in the bundle.

can-stache.expressions.name: can-stache.expressions
can-stache.expressions.title: Expressions
can-stache.expressions.description:
In addition to different magic tag types, stache supports different expression
types.  These can be used in various combinations to call helper methods
or viewModel methods.  The following is an example of all the expressions
combined:

can-stache.helpers.is.name: can-stache.helpers.is
can-stache.helpers.is.title: {{#is expressions}}
can-stache.helpers.is.description: Render something if two values are equal.

can-stache.registerSimpleHelper.name: can-stache.registerSimpleHelper
can-stache.registerSimpleHelper.title: registerSimpleHelper
can-stache.registerSimpleHelper.description: Register a helper that gets passed values.

can-stache.helpers.with.name: can-stache.helpers.with
can-stache.helpers.with.title: {{#with expression}}
can-stache.helpers.with.description: Changes the context within a block.

can-stache/keys/at.name: can-stache/keys/at
can-stache/keys/at.title: @at
can-stache/keys/at.description:
Return whatever value is at a key, regardless
if it's a function or a compute.

can-stache/keys/compute.name: can-stache/keys/compute
can-stache/keys/compute.title: ~compute
can-stache/keys/compute.description:
Pass a compute instead of a value if an observable is found within
call.

can-stache/keys/current.name: can-stache/keys/current
can-stache/keys/current.title: ./current
can-stache/keys/current.description: Lookup a value in only the current context.

can-stache.key.name: can-stache.key
can-stache.key.title: key
can-stache.key.description: A named reference to a value in the scope or helper scope in a template.

can-stache/keys/parent.name: can-stache/keys/parent
can-stache/keys/parent.title: ../parent
can-stache/keys/parent.description: Start looking for values in the parent context.

can-stache/keys/special.name: can-stache/keys/special
can-stache/keys/special.title: %special
can-stache/keys/special.description:
Event bindings and some helpers like can-stache.helpers.each
provide special values that start with % to prevent potential collisions with
other values.

can-stache/keys/this.name: can-stache/keys/this
can-stache/keys/this.title: this
can-stache/keys/this.description: Write out or return the current context.

can-stache/keys/variable.name: can-stache/keys/variable
can-stache/keys/variable.title: *variable
can-stache/keys/variable.description: Store a variable local to the template.

can-stache/helpers/route.name: can-stache/helpers/route
can-stache/helpers/route.description: Adds stache helpers that use can-route.

can-stache.helpers.routeCurrent.name: can-stache.helpers.routeCurrent
can-stache.helpers.routeCurrent.title: {{#routeCurrent hash}}
can-stache.helpers.routeCurrent.description: Returns if the hash values match the can-route's current properties.

can-stache.tags.comment.name: can-stache.tags.comment
can-stache.tags.comment.title: {{!expression}}
can-stache.tags.comment.description: A comment that doesn't get inserted into the rendered result.

can-stache.tags.escaped.name: can-stache.tags.escaped
can-stache.tags.escaped.title: {{expression}}
can-stache.tags.escaped.description: Insert the value of the expression into the output of the template.

can-stache.tags.inverse.name: can-stache.tags.inverse
can-stache.tags.inverse.title: {{^expression}}
can-stache.tags.inverse.description:
Like can-stache.tags.section, but renders the opposite subsection depending on the type of expression
or the expression's return value.

manages the errors for the current property within the errors object.

guides/recipes/file-navigator-advanced.name: guides/recipes/file-navigator-advanced
guides/recipes/file-navigator-advanced.title: File Navigator Guide (Advanced)
guides/recipes/file-navigator-advanced.description:
This guide walks you through building a file navigation widget.  It takes about 45 minutes to complete.  It was written with
CanJS 3.4. Checkout the file-navigator-simple
for an easier example that produces similar functionality.

guides/recipes/file-navigator-simple.name: guides/recipes/file-navigator-simple
guides/recipes/file-navigator-simple.title: File Navigator Guide (Simple)
guides/recipes/file-navigator-simple.description:
This guide walks you through building a simple file navigation widget.  It takes about 25 minutes to complete.  It was written with
CanJS 3.4. Checkout the file-navigator-advanced
for an example that makes AJAX requests for its data and uses can-component.

guides/recipes.name: guides/recipes
guides/recipes.title: Recipes
guides/recipes.description: A listing of small examples that are useful for learning CanJS.

guides/atm.name: guides/atm
guides/atm.title: ATM Guide
guides/atm.description:
This guide will walk you through building and testing an Automated Teller Machine (ATM) application with CanJS’s
Core libraries.  You’ll learn how to do test driven development (TDD)
and manage complex state.  It takes about 2 hours to complete.

guides/chat.name: guides/chat
guides/chat.title: Chat Guide
guides/chat.description: This guide will walk you through building a real-time chat application with CanJS’s Core libraries.  It takes about 30 minutes to complete.

guides/todomvc.name: guides/todomvc
guides/todomvc.title: TodoMVC Guide
guides/todomvc.description: This guide will walk you through building a slightly modified version of TodoMVC with CanJS’s Core libraries and can-fixture. It takes about 1 hour to complete.

can-util/dom/events/attributes/attribute.name: can-util/dom/events/attributes/attributes
can-util/dom/events/attributes/attribute.title: attributes
can-util/dom/events/attributes/attribute.description:
Adds a listenable "attributes" event to DOM nodes, which fires when
the node's attributes change.

can-util/dom/events/delegate/delegate.name: can-util/dom/events/delegate/delegate
can-util/dom/events/delegate/delegate.title: delegateEvents
can-util/dom/events/delegate/delegate.description:
Add delegate listeners to DOM events.  Delegated listeners use a selector on an
ancestor element to determine when to fire the event for an item.  This can help
cases where large numbers of similar DOM nodes are added into a DOM subtree, since
event handlers do not have to be attached to each new node.

can-util/dom/events/inserted/inserted.description: This event fires when the bound element is added to the DOM.

can-util/dom/events/enter/enter.title: enter
can-util/dom/events/enter/enter.description: Watches for when enter keys are pressed on a given element

can-util/dom/events/radiochange/radiocha.title: radiochange
can-util/dom/events/radiochange/radiocha.description:
Adds a listenable "radiochange" event to DOM nodes, which fires when
any radio input changes.

guides/recipes/todomvc-with-steal.name: guides/recipes/todomvc-with-steal
guides/recipes/todomvc-with-steal.title: TodoMVC with StealJS
guides/recipes/todomvc-with-steal.description: This guide walks through building TodoMVC with StealJS.

guides/recipes/playlist-editor.name: guides/recipes/playlist-editor
guides/recipes/playlist-editor.title: Playlist Editor (Advanced)
guides/recipes/playlist-editor.description:
Learn how to use YouTube's API to search for videos and make a playlist.  This makes authenticated requests with OAuth2. It uses jQuery++ for
drag/drop events. It shows using custom attributes and custom events.  This guide takes
an hour to complete.

guides/recipes/weather-report-advanced.name: guides/recipes/weather-report-advanced
guides/recipes/weather-report-advanced.title: Weather Report Guide (Advanced)
guides/recipes/weather-report-advanced.description:
This guides you through extending the Simple Weather Report Guide to remove imperative code and automatically look up the user’s location using the
browser’s geolocation API.  Both of these will be done with event streams.
This guide continues where the Simple Weather Report Guide left off.  It takes about 25 minutes to complete.  It was written with CanJS 3.8.

guides/recipes/weather-report-simple.name: guides/recipes/weather-report-simple
guides/recipes/weather-report-simple.title: Weather Report Guide (Simple)
guides/recipes/weather-report-simple.description:
This guide walks you through building a simple weather report widget.  It takes about 25 minutes to complete.  It was written with
CanJS 3.5.
